The people of this station, in their states, have their mouths agape; the lights of the Essence (أنوار الذات) have overwhelmed them, and the traces of the Attributes (رسوم الصفات) have appeared upon them. They are the hidden brides of Allah, veiled with Him, whom none knows but He, just as they do not know. He crowned them with the crown of splendor (*al-baha’*) and the wreath of radiance (*al-sana’*), and seated them upon the pulpits of annihilation (*fana’*) from proximity, on the carpet of intimacy (*uns*), and the private conversation of Eternity (*al-daymumiyya*) with the tongue of Self-Subsistence (*al-qayyumiyya*). This bequeathed them His saying: <<عَلَى صَلَاتِهِمْ دَائِمُونَ>> (They are constant in their prayer) and <<وَبِشَهَادَاتِهِمْ قَائِمُونَ>> (And they are standing by their testimonies). The Divine Power (القوة الإلهية) continuously supplies them with witnessing (*mushahada*), so they manifest with the Attributes in the place of the two feet. They are only bewildered in terms of emulation, and they only mention Him to establish a tradition (*sunna*) or an obligation (*fard*). They do not deviate from the straight path. They are with the Real (الحق), even if they address and associate with creation (الخلق). They are not with them, and even if they see them, they do not see them, for they only see them as being among the Acts of Allah (أفعال الله). They witness the artifact (*al-san‘a*) and the Artisan (*al-sani‘*) in a continuous station (*maqaman ‘umriyyan*), just as one of you sits with a carpenter making a coffin, witnessing the artifact and the Artisan, and the artifact does not veil him from the Artisan, unless the beauty of the artifact preoccupies his heart.

For the world, as the Prophet (peace be upon him) said, is sweet and green, and it is like the greenness of the dung heap—a beautiful running woman in a bad environment. Whoever treats her well and loves her, she treats him badly and deprives him of his Hereafter.

And well did the poet say:
When a wise man tests the world, it unveils itself to him
As an enemy in the clothes of a friend.

This group, the Trustworthy, the Truthful Ones (*al-Siddiqun*), when Allah supports them with Divine Power and supplies them, they are with Him in this proportional manner, by way of example. This is the highest station to which one ascends and the noblest goal to which one arrives. This is the ultimate goal, since there is no goal except in terms of Unity (التوحيد), not in terms of resources and incoming states. It is the Level One (*al-Mustawi*), since there is no level except the Highest Companion (*al-Rafiq al-A‘la*). Congratulations to this band for what they have attained of the realities of witnessing (*haqa’iq al-mushahada*), and congratulations to us for affirming and submitting to them with agreement and assistance.

### [Return to the Beginning: The Basmala through the Path of Secrets]

The steed of the tongue has passed us in the arena of speech, so let us return to what we were discussing. Peace be upon you. I say: The omitted hamza of this Name, due to the annexation, is the realization of the connection of Oneness (الوحدانية) and the eradication of the separation of jealousy (*al-ghayra*). The attached *Alif* and *Lām*, as mentioned before, are for realizing the connected and erasing the separated. The *Alif* existing in the second *Lām* is for erasing the traces of the acquired other (*al-ghayr al-mutahassal*). The *Wāw* (و) that follows the *Hā’* (ه) has no trace in the script, but its meaning in Existence (الوجود) is the splendor (*baha’*) of the Ipseity (*al-Huwiyya*) that has spread. He manifested it in the World of Sovereignty (*‘alam al-mulk*) by its Essence (ذاتها), saying: <<هُوَ اللهُ الَّذِي لَا إِلَٰهَ إِلَّا هُوَ>> (He is Allah, besides whom there is no god). So He began with the Ipseity (*al-Huwiyya*) and concluded with it, and He granted it dominion over the matter in Existence and non-existence. He made it indicative of origination (*al-huduth*) and pre-eternity (*al-qidam*). It is the last and highest remembrance of those who remember. Thus, the end returned to the beginning, and the Night of Power (*Laylat al-Qadr*) shone forth. By its existence, the people of divine care and support stood upon the realities of Unity (حقائق التوحيد). Existence (الوجود) is quiescent in the dot of the circle of this Name, and it encompasses it by its reality, just as places encompass the quiescent inhabitant. <<وَلِلَّهِ الْمَثَلُ الْأَعْلَىٰ>> (And to Allah belongs the highest example).

And Allah has set the lesser as an example for His light,
A similitude of the Niche and the Lamp.

Then He the Exalted said: <<أَلَا إِنَّهُ بِكُلِّ شَيْءٍ مُّحِيطٌ>> (Indeed, He encompasses all things) and <<أَحَاطَ بِكُلِّ شَيْءٍ عِلْمًا>> (He encompasses all things in knowledge). He made the totality a Name and a Named, and sent it forth unveiled and veiled. (Solving the Locked and Detailing the Summarized).

### [Allah: Through the Path of Secrets]

The servant says *Allah*, thereby affirming the First and the Last, and negating the Inner and the Outer by the two *Lām*s (ل). The second *Lām* adhered to the *Hā’* (ه) through the mediation of the *Alif* of Knowledge (*al-Alif al-‘Ilmiyya*): <<مَا يَكُونُ مِن نَّجْوَىٰ ثَلَاثَةٍ إِلَّا هُوَ رَابِعُهُمْ>> (There is no private conversation of three except that He is the fourth of them)—the three are the *Lām*s—<<وَلَا خَمْسَةٍ إِلَّا هُوَ سَادِسُهُمْ>> (nor five except that He is the sixth of them). The *Alif* is the sixth in relation to the *Hā’*, and the fourth in relation to the *Lām*. <<أَلَمْ تَرَ إِلَىٰ رَبِّكَ كَيْفَ مَدَّ الظِّلَّ>> (Have you not considered your Lord, how He extends the shadow?) The Throne (*al-‘Arsh*) is the shadow of Allah. The Throne is the second *Lām*, and what it contains is the first *Lām* by way of sovereignty (*al-mulk*). The two *Lām*s are the Outer (*al-Zahir*) and the Inner (*al-Batin*) in terms of the Names. They appeared between the *Alif* of the First (*al-Awwal*) and the *Alif* of the Last (*al-Akhir*). This is the station of connection, because the end bends back upon the beginning and connects with it in a connection of union. Then the *Hā’* emerged with its inner *Wāw* (و) as an emergence of separation. The connected part between the *Lām* and the *Hā’* is the secret by which witnessing (*mushahada*) occurs between the servant and the Master. That is the center of the *Alif* of Knowledge (*al-Alif al-‘Ilmiyya*), which is the station of dissolution (*al-idmihlal*). Then the Exalted placed a connected part in the script between the two *Lām*s for the connection between the first *Lām*, which is the World of Sovereignty (*‘alam al-mulk*), and the second *Lām*, which is the World of Dominion (*‘alam al malakut*). This is the center of the Middle World, the World of Power (*‘alam al-Jabarut*), the station of the Soul (*al-Nafs*). It does not have a subsisting essence like the two *Lām*s, for it is in the position of the World of Imagination (*‘alam al-Khayal*) for us. There must be empty lines between every two letters, and those are the stations of the annihilation of the traces of the wayfarers (*rusum al-salikin*) from one Presence to another.

### [Completion: The Five Letters of Majesty and the Five General Realities]

The first *Alif*, which is the *Alif* of the hamza, is disconnected. The *Alif* of the second *Lām* is connected to it. The *Alif* was disconnected at the beginning of the lines due to the Prophet’s saying (peace be upon him): "Allah was, and there was nothing with Him." For this reason, it is disconnected, and every letter that resembles it in not connecting to what follows it is purified from the letters. The letters that resemble it are equal to the number of the high general realities (الحقائق العامة العالية) which are the Mothers (*al-Ummahat*). Likewise, if it is the last of the letters, it cuts off the connection from the numerical posteriority. The disconnection of the *Alif* was a notification of what we mentioned, and likewise its brethren (د ذ ر ز). In all realities, there is a body that is nourished, sensitive, and speaking, and what is besides it that has language. The universal realities of the World are confined. When He desired the existence of the second *Lām*—which is the first existing thing in meaning, even if it is delayed in the script, for the knowledge of the body precedes the knowledge of the spirit in witnessing, and likewise the script in witnessing—which is the World of Dominion (*‘alam al-Malakut*), He brought it into existence by His Power (القدرة), which is the hamza in the Name when you begin it stripped of annexation. It does not separate from the *Alif*. When this *Alif* brought the second *Lām* into existence, He made it a chief. It naturally sought a subordinate to rule over. So He brought into existence for it the World of Witnessing (*‘alam al-Shahada*), which is the first *Lām*. When it looked at it, it shone and illuminated: <<وَأَشْرَقَتِ الْأَرْضُ بِنُورِ رَبِّهَا>> (And the earth will shine with the light of its Lord). And <<وَوُضِعَ الْكِتَابُ>> (And the record will be placed) is the part between the two *Lām*s. The Glorious commanded the second *Lām* to supply the first with what the Exalted supplied it from the bounty of His Essence (جود ذاته), and to be its guide to Him. It requested from Him a meaning for its disposal in all its affairs, to be like a minister for it, to whom it would convey what it desired, and he would convey it to the World of the first *Lām*. So He brought into existence for it the part connected to the two *Lām*s, expressed as the Middle Book (*al-Kitab al-Awsat*), which is the World of Power (*al-‘alam al-Jabaruti*). It does not have a subsisting essence like the two *Lām*s, for it is, for us, in the position of the World of Imagination (*‘alam al-Khayal*). The second *Lām* conveyed to that part, and what was desired from it was inscribed therein, and it was directed with it to the first *Lām*. It complied with obedience until it said: "Yes (*balā*)." When the first *Lām* saw that the command had come to it from the second *Lām* through the mediation of the part (which is the Law/Sharī‘a), it became a witness (*mushahida*) to what came to it from that part, desiring that it connect it to the Master of the Command so that it might witness Him. When it directed its aspiration (*himma*) to that part and became preoccupied with witnessing it, it became veiled from the *Alif* that preceded it: <<ارْجِعُوا وَرَاءَكُمْ فَالْتَمِسُوا نُورًا>> (Go back behind you and seek light). Had it not directed its aspiration to that part, it would have received the command from the first *Alif* without mediation. But this is impossible due to a great secret, for that is the *Alif* of the Essence (ألف الذات), and the second is the *Alif* of Knowledge (ألف العلم).

### [Indication: The Lām of Majesty and the Alif of Unity]

Do you not see that the second *Lām*, since it was desired, chosen, and purified from mediators, connected to the *Alif* of Unity (ألف الوحدانية) with a complete connection, such that its existence became a pronunciation that correctly indicates the *Alif*? Even though the Essence (الذات) is hidden, your pronunciation of the *Lām* confirms the connection and guides you to it. "Whoever knows himself knows his Lord." Whoever knows the second *Lām* knows the *Alif*. So make yourself a guide to yourself, and then make your being a guide to yourself a guide to Him for those who are distant. He prioritized the servant's knowledge of himself over his knowledge of his Lord, and then after that, He annihilates him from the knowledge of himself, since the desired goal for him was to know his Lord. Do you not see the embrace of the *Lām* and the *Alif*, and how the *Lām* exists in pronunciation before the *Alif*? In this is a notification for the one who comprehends. This *Lām* of Dominion (*malakutiyya*) receives from the *Alif* of Unity without mediation, conveying it to the part of Power (*Jabaruti*) so that it may deliver it to the *Lām* of Witnessing and Sovereignty (*al-mulk*). This is the matter as long as there is composition and veil. When the Firstness and Lastness, the Outer and the Inner, were established, He the Exalted desired, just as He presented the *Alif* purified from connection with the letters in all respects, to make the end similar to the beginning. Thus, no subsistence (*baqa’*) is valid for the servant, neither first nor last. So He made the *Hā’* (ه) singular with the *Wāw* of its Ipseity (*Huwiyya*). If someone imagines that the *Hā’* is attached to the *Lām*, it is not so. Rather, it is after the *Alif* that follows the *Lām*, and nothing connects to the *Alif* in posteriority among the letters. So the *Hā’* after the *Lām* is cut off from everything. That connection to the *Lām* in the script is not a connection. The *Hā’* is one, and the *Alif* is one. Multiply the one by its like, and it will be one. Thus, the separation of creation (الخلق) from the Real (الحق) is confirmed, and the Real remains. When the moral quality (*takhalluq*) of the *Lām* of Sovereignty is confirmed by what the *Lām* of Dominion conveys to it, it continuously dissolves from its Attributes and is annihilated from its traces until it attains the station of annihilation from itself (*fana’ ‘an nafsiha*). When it is annihilated from its essence, the part is annihilated due to its annihilation, and the two *Lām*s unite in pronunciation, articulated by the tongue as doubled due to the assimilation (*idgham*) that occurred. Thus, it came to exist between two *Alif*s that encompassed and surrounded it. The bestowed wisdom gave us this: when we heard the utterance of the speaker without a *Bā’* between two *Alif*s, we knew by necessary knowledge that the originated (*al-muhdath*) was annihilated by the manifestation of the Pre-eternal (*al-Qadim*). Thus, two *Alif*s remained, a first and a last, and the Outer and the Inner vanished with the vanishing of the two *Lām*s by the word of negation. We multiplied the *Alif* by the *Alif*, the multiplication of one by one, and the *Hā’* emerged for you. When it appeared, the ruling of the First and the Last, which He made the mediator, vanished, just as the ruling of the Outer and the Inner vanished. It was then said: "Allah was, and there was nothing with Him." The origin of this pronoun, the *Hā’*, must be the nominative case (*al-raf‘*). If it is opened or lowered, that is an Attribute that returns to the one who opened or lowered it, returning to the agent that preceded it in the utterance.

### [Completion: Vowels, Letters, and Articulation Points in the Name of Majesty]

Then the Glorious brought into existence the vowels (*al-harakat*), the letters (*al-huruf*), and the articulation points (*al-makharij*), as a notification from Him, the Glorious and Exalted, that essences (*al-dhawat*) are distinguished by Attributes (الصفات) and stations (*al-maqamat*). He made the vowels analogous to the Attributes, the letters analogous to the Described (*al-Mawsuf*), and the articulation points analogous to the stations and ascensions (*al-ma‘arij*). He gave this Name, in all its aspects of connection and disconnection, the letters: *Hamza*, *Alif*, *Lām*, *Hā’*, and *Wāw* (ء أ ل ه و). The *Hamza* is first, and the *Hā’* is last, or their articulation point is one, near the heart. Then He placed the letter *Lām* between the *Hamza* and the *Hā’*, and its articulation point is the tongue, the interpreter of the heart. Thus, the relation between the two *Lām*s and the *Hamza* and the *Hā’* occurred, just as the relation occurred between the heart, which is the locus of speech, and the tongue, which interprets it. Al-Akhtal said:

Indeed, speech is in the heart, and the tongue
Was only made a guide to the heart.

Since the *Lām* is from the tongue, He made it look toward Him, not toward itself, and annihilated it from itself—which is the lower palate. When it looked toward Him, not toward its own essence, it ascended and rose to the upper palate, and the tongue became firm with it in the palate, a firmness of empowerment, due to its ascent and elevation by witnessing Him. The *Wāw* emerged from the two lips into manifest Existence (الوجود الظاهر), informing and indicating Him. That is the inner station of Prophethood (باطن النبوة), which is the hair (*al-sha‘ra*) of the Messenger (peace be upon him) that is in us. In that lies the inheritance (*al-wirth*). It emerged from this connection that the *Hamza*, the *Alif*, and the *Hā’* are from the World of Dominion (*‘alam al-Malakut*), the *Lām* is from the World of Power (*‘alam al-Jabarut*), and the *Wāw* is from the World of Sovereignty (*‘alam al-Mulk*).

### [Continuation: The Name Ar-Rahman, through the Path of Secrets]

Concerning *Ar-Rahman* (الرَّحْمنِ) in the *Basmala*: The discussion of this Name in this chapter is from two perspectives: the perspective of the Essence (الذات) and the perspective of the Attribute (الصفة). Whoever parses it as an appositive (*badal*) makes it the Essence, and whoever parses it as an adjective (*na‘t*) makes it the Attribute. The Attributes are six, and the condition for these Attributes is Life (الحياة), so the seven appeared. All these Attributes belong to the Essence, which is the *Alif* existing between the *Mīm* and the *Nūn* of *Ar-Rahman*. The discussion of this Name is structured upon the sound report from the Prophet (peace be upon him): "Allah created Adam upon His image," in terms of the pronoun referring back to Allah. This view is supported by the other narration: His saying (peace be upon him): "Upon the image of *Ar-Rahman*." Although this narration is not authenticated by the transmitters, it is sound through the path of Unveiling (*al-Kashf*). I say: The *Alif*, the *Lām*, and the *Rā’* (أ ل ر) are for Knowledge (*al-‘Ilm*), Will (*al-Irada*), and Power (*al-Qudra*). The *Hā’*, the *Mīm*, and the *Nūn* (ح م ن) are the referents of Speech (*al-Kalam*), Hearing (*al-Sam‘*), and Sight (*al-Basar*). The conditional Attribute, which is Life (*al-Hayat*), accompanies all these Attributes. Then the *Alif* between the *Mīm* and the *Nūn* is the referent of the Described One (*al-Mawsuf*). It was omitted in the script because the Attributes necessarily indicate it, based on the subsistence of the Attribute by the Described. Thus, the Attributes manifested to the World, and for this reason, they know nothing of the Deity other than them, nor do they know them. What necessarily indicates the existence of the *Alif* is what we mentioned, plus the lengthening of the *fatha* (vowel) of the *Mīm*. This is a Divine indication of the expansion of mercy upon the World. The letter preceding the *Alif* is always open (*maftuh*). Thus, the *fatha* indicates the *Alif* in this context, which is the locus of the existence of the Spirit (*al-Ruh*), which has the station of expansion (*al-bast*) for the locus of Theophany (*al-Tajalli*). For this reason, the scholars of composition, in setting the script for the weak letters (*huruf al-‘illa*), mentioned the *Yā’* preceded by a *kasra* (vowel), since a sound *Yā’* may exist without a preceding *kasra*, and likewise the *Wāw* preceded by a *damma* (vowel). But when they mentioned the *Alif*, they did not say "preceded by a *fatha*," since it never exists except with a *fatha* on the preceding letter, unlike the *Wāw* and the *Yā’*. Moderation is always necessary for the *Alif*. The ignorant person, when he knows nothing in Existence purified from all imperfections except Allah the Exalted, forgets the Highest Holy Spirit (*al-Ruh al-Qudusi al-A‘la*) and says: "There is nothing in Existence but Allah." But when asked for detail, he has no realization. They specified the *Wāw* with a preceding *damma* and the *Yā’* with a preceding *kasra* for what we mentioned. Thus, the distinction between the *Alif* and the *Wāw* and *Yā’* is confirmed. The *Alif* is for the Essence (الذات), the *Wāw* of elevation is for the Attributes (الصفات), and the *Yā’* of elevation is for the Acts (الأفعال). The *Alif* is for the Spirit, and the Intellect is its Attribute, which is the *fatha* (opening). The *Wāw* is the Soul (*al-Nafs*), and contraction (*al-qabd*) is its Attribute, which is the *damma* (closing). The *Yā’* is the Body, and the existence of the Act is its Attribute, which is the *khafd* (lowering). If the letter preceding the *Wāw* or *Yā’* is opened, that refers back to the state of the addressee. Since they are necessarily others (*ghayr*), the Attributes differed upon them. Since the *Alif* does not accept vowels, it united with its referent, and nothing differed upon it at all. They were called the letters of defect (*huruf al-‘illa*) for what we shall mention. The *Alif* of the Essence is the cause (*‘illa*) for the existence of the Attribute. The *Wāw* of the Attribute is the cause for the existence of the Act. The *Yā’* of the Act is the cause for the existence of what issues from it in the World of Witnessing (عالم الشهادة) in terms of movement and quiescence. For this reason, they are called causes (*‘ilal*). Then He brought into existence the *Nūn* (ن) of this Name as half a circle in shape, and the other half is contained and intelligible in the dot that indicates the hidden *Nūn* (النون الغيبية), which is the other half of the circle. People assume the dot is merely an indicator of the sensible *Nūn*. Then He brought into existence the beginning of the *Hā’* (ح) near the *Alif* omitted in the script, as an indication of witnessing it. For this reason, it is quiescent. Had its beginning been near the *Rā’*, it would have been vocalized. The first *Alif* is for Knowledge, the *Lām* is for Will, and the *Rā’* is for Power, which is the Attribute of bringing into existence (*al-Ijad*). We found the *Alif* has movement, being a hamza, and the *Rā’* has movement, while the *Lām* is quiescent. Thus, Will united with Power, just as Knowledge and Will united with Power when you connect *Ar-Rahman* to *Allah*. The *Lām* of Will was assimilated (*idgham*) into the *Rā’* of Power after being converted to a *Rā’* and doubled, to confirm the bringing into existence (*al-Ijad*), which is the *Hā’*—the existence of the Word (*al-Kalima*) being quiescent. It is quiescent because it is indivisible, while movement is divisible. Since the *Hā’* is physically quiescent and we see it adjacent to the *Rā’* of Power, we know that it is the Word and its octuple nature.

### [Note: Ar-Rahman as Appositive or Adjective, or the Station of Gathering and Separation]

The one who parses it as an appositive (*badal*) of *Allah* refers to the station of Gathering (مقام الجمع) and the union of Attributes, which is the station of those who narrated: "Adam was created upon His image." That is the existence of the servant in the station of the Real (الحق), the boundary of Vicegerency (*al-Khilafa*). Vicegerency necessarily requires sovereignty (*al-mulk*). Sovereignty is divided into two parts: one related to its Essence, and one related to its other. One of these divisions is suitable in this station according to the arrangement we established. For the appositive in this position takes the place of the thing substituted, like our saying: "Your brother Zayd came to me," where Zayd is the substitute for your brother. The substitution of a thing for a thing, and they are one and the same essence, for Zayd is your brother, and your brother is Zayd, without doubt. This is the station of the one who believes the opposite, for he has not stood upon reality nor ever unified an existing thing. As for the one who parses it as an adjective (*na‘t*), he refers to the station of Separation (مقام التفرقة) in the Attribute, which is the station of those who narrated: "Adam was created upon the image of *Ar-Rahman*." This is the station of Inheritance (*al-Wiratha*), and it only occurs between two others, the station of the veil due to the occultation of the One and the manifestation of the second, which is expressed as the exemplar (*al-mathal*). In what we have established is proof of what we have concealed, so understand. Then He manifested the lower half of the *Nūn* (ن), which is the visible half of the revolving sphere, from the half-circle. The center of the World is in the middle of the line that extends from one end of the half to the other. The second half, concealed in the dot, is the half hidden from us, beneath the opposite of the line in relation to us, since our vision is in one direction in terms of Act. The half existing in the script is the East (*al-Mashriq*), and the half gathered in the dot is the West (*al-Maghrib*), which is the rising place of the existence of secrets. The East, which is the manifest composite, is divisible, and the West, which is the inner simple, is indivisible. Concerning this, I say:

How wondrous is the manifest that is divisible,
And its inner that is indivisible.
The manifest is a sun in Aries,
And the inner is in a mighty Leo.
Realize and look at a meaning that was veiled
Beneath its coverings, the darkness.
If the hidden is that which appeared,
How wondrous, by Allah, they are both the division.
So hasten to the sun and leave the moon,
Which appears and vanishes in the odd number.
And remove the sandals of my two cosmic feet;
Make my knowledge an even number, and the Word will be.

For this reason, Knowledge relates to the known things, the single Will relates to the willed things, and the single Power relates to the empowered things. Division and enumeration occur in the empowered, known, and willed things, which is the half existing in the script. Union and purification from the inner Attributes of Knowledge, Power, and Will occur. In this is an indication, so understand. Since the *Hā’* (ح) is eight, which is the existence of the perfection of the Essence (كمال الذات), and for this reason we expressed it as the Word (*al-Kalima*) and the Spirit (*al-Ruh*), likewise the *Nūn* (ن) is the fifth in the tens, since the *Mīm* (م), which is the fourth, precedes it. The *Nūn* is corporeal (*jismani*), the locus for bringing into existence the substances of the Spirit, the Intellect, the Soul, and the existence of the Act. All of this is deposited in the *Nūn*, which is the manifest universality of the human (*kulliyyat al-insan*). For this reason, it appeared.

### [Completion: The Separation of the Mīm and the Nūn by the Alif]

The *Mīm* and the *Nūn* were separated by the *Alif* of the barrier (*Alif Man*) because the *Mīm* is of the realm of Dominion (*malakutiyya*), as we made it for the Spirit, and the *Nūn* is of the realm of Sovereignty (*malakiyya*), and the dot is of the realm of Power (*jabarutiyya*) due to the existence of the secret of negating claim. It is as if He says: O Spirit, which is the *Mīm*, We did not choose you because of what you are, but rather due to a pre-existing care for you in scientific existence. If We wished, We would have revealed the dot of the Intellect and the *Nūn* of humanity without the mediation of your existence. So know yourself and know that this is a specification for you from Me, based on who I am, not based on who you are. Thus, the chosen status (*al-istifa’iyya*) was confirmed. So, Theophany (*tajalli*) never occurs for anyone else. Praise be to Allah for what He has bestowed. Be aware, O poor one, of the existence of the *Mīm* circling in the form of the body, with precedence, how it indicates purification from divisibility. The division of the circle is endless, so the division of the Spirit of the *Mīm* by its known things is endless, yet in its essence, it is indivisible. Then look at the *Mīm* when it is separated alone, how the substance of perspiration (*al-ta‘riq*) appeared from it when it descended to the existence of the Act in the world of address and obligation. The substance became related to the other, not to its own essence, since the circle indicates it specifically. What is added is not related to its right, since its essence is established. It can only be related to the right of its other. When the servant looked at the substance, he extended perspiration. This is the existence of realization (*al-tahqiq*). Then know that the connected part between the *Mīm* and the *Nūn* is the center of the *Alif* of the Essence (ألف الذات). The *Alif* was hidden so that the connection between the *Mīm* and the *Nūn* might occur by way of the substance, which is the connected part. Had the *Alif* appeared, the perspiration of the *Mīm* would not have been valid, because the *Alif* would have stood between them. In this is a notification of His saying: <<رَبِّ السَّمَاوَاتِ وَالْأَرْضِ وَمَا بَيْنَهُمَا الرَّحْمَٰنُ>> (Lord of the heavens and the earth and whatever is between them, the All-Merciful). The existence of the desired *Alif* here is based on parsing it as a subject (*mubtada’*), which is not valid grammatically. The correct parsing is as an appositive (*badal*) of the Lord (*al-Rabb*). Thus, the *Alif* here represents the Spirit (*al-Ruh*), and the Real (الحق) subsists by all. The *Mīm* is the heavens, and the *Nūn* is the earth. If the *Alif* appears between the *Mīm* and the *Nūn*, the connection is with the *Mīm*, not the *Nūn*. The *Nūn* never takes an Attribute without mediation, due to its disconnection. Its connection to the *Mīm* indicates taking without mediation. The non-existence by which the disconnection was confirmed annihilates the *Nūn*, and the *Mīm* remains veiled from the secret of its pre-eternity (*sirr qidamihi*) by the dot in its center, which is the hollow of its circle, when looking at its essence after it was not in what appeared to it.

### [Question and Answer]

You knew the secret of His pre-eternity, yet He did not know Himself, though He is more entitled to know Himself than you, if you look at your manifest aspect. Or, is the World, by the secret of pre-eternity within it, the meaning existing in you, the one speaking about it, which is the *Mīm* of the Spirit? He has stood upon the secret of His pre-eternity. The answer to that is that the one among us who knew the secret of pre-eternity is the one We veiled there. Thus, the aspect by which We affirmed knowledge for him is different from the aspect by which We affirmed lack of knowledge for him. We say that he attained that by knowledge (*‘ilm*), not by essence (*‘ayn*). This exists. It is not a condition for one who knows something to see it. Vision (*al-ru’ya*) of the known thing is more complete than knowledge of it from one perspective, and clearer in gnosis (*ma‘rifa*) of it. Every essence (*‘ayn*) is knowledge, but not all knowledge is essence. It is not a condition for one who knows that Mecca exists to have seen it. But if he sees it, we are certain that he knows it. I do not mean the Name. The essence (*al-‘ayn*) has a known degree over knowledge, as was said:

But for direct vision (*al-‘iyan*) there is a subtle meaning,
Which is why the Interlocutor (*al-Kalim*) asked for observation.

Rather, I say that the reality of the secret of pre-eternity, which is the certain truth (*haqq al-yaqin*), is not observed, so he did not witness it, because it returns to an existing Essence. If he knew an existing Essence, it would be a deficiency in his right. The ultimate perfection for him is the knowledge of himself by his existence after he was not, essentially (*‘aynan*). This is a wondrous distinction; if you contemplate it, you will stand upon wonders. So understand.

### [The Connection of the Lām and the Rā’—in the Name Ar-Rahman—Phonetically]

The *Lām* connected to the *Rā’* with a connection of union phonetically, since they are two inner Attributes, so union was easy for them. The *Hā’* (ح), which is the Word expressed as the empowered thing (*al-maqdur*), was found separated from the *Rā’*, which is Power (*al-Qudra*), so that the empowered thing might be distinguished from Power, and so that the empowered *Hā’* would not be imagined to be an Attribute of the Essence of Power. Thus, the distinction between the Pre-eternal (*al-Qadim*) and the originated (*al-muhdath*) occurred. So understand, may Allah have mercy on you.

### [Ar-Rahman: Indefinite and Definite]

You should know that *Rahman* (رحمان), without the *Alif* and *Lām*, is the Name and belongs to the Essence (الذات). The *Alif* and *Lām* of definition are the Attributes (الصفات). For this reason, *Rahman* is said when they are removed, just as *Essence* is said, and it is not called an Attribute with them. Look at the name of Musaylima the Liar; he called himself *Rahman* but was not guided to the *Alif* and *Lām*, because the Essence is the locus of claim for everyone, but by the Attributes the claimant is exposed. *Rahman* is the station of Gathering (مقام الجمع), which is the station of ignorance. The noblest thing one can ascend to on the path of Allah is ignorance of Him the Exalted, and gnosis of Him is ignorance of Him, for that is the reality of servanthood (*al-‘ubudiyya*). The Exalted said: <<وَأَنفِقُوا مِمَّا جَعَلَكُم مُّسْتَخْلَفِينَ فِيهِ>> (And spend from that over which He has made you successors). He stripped you bare. What supports this is His saying: <<وَمَا أُوتِيتُم مِّنَ الْعِلْمِ إِلَّا قَلِيلًا>> (And you have not been given of knowledge except a little), and His saying: <<الَّذِينَ آتَيْنَاهُمُ الْكِتَابَ يَتْلُونَهُ حَقَّ تِلَاوَتِهِ>> (Those to whom We have given the Book recite it with its true recitation). By the reality of vicegerency (*al-istikhlaf*), Musaylima, Iblis, and the Dajjal were stripped. Their state was known. Had they deserved it essentially, they would never have been stripped of it. But if you look with the eye of execution and total acceptance, not with the eye of command, you will find the opponent obedient and the crooked one straight, and all are within the bond of servitude, whether they wish it or not. As for Iblis and Musaylima, they explicitly declared servanthood, while the Dajjal refused. Reflect on where each of them spoke from, and what realities manifested to them that necessitated these states.

### [Completion: The Omission of the Alif and the Lām Phonetically in the Basmala]

When we pronounce *Bismillah ar-Rahman ar-Rahim*, the *Alif* and *Lām* do not appear in existence phonetically. Thus, the connection becomes from Essence to Essence, and *Allah* and *Ar-Rahman* are two Names for the Essence. So He returned upon Himself by Himself. For this reason, the Prophet (peace be upon him) said: "And I seek refuge in You from You." When he reached the Essence, he saw no other. Yet he said, "I seek refuge in You," and there must be something sought refuge from. So it was unveiled to him, and he said, "from You." And "from You" is Him. The proof of this is "I seek refuge," and separation is not valid, for it is in the Essence, and separation is not permissible therein. It is clear from this that the word *Allah* is the servant. Just as the word *Allah* is an indicator of the Essence, so too is the comprehensive universal servant. The servant is the word of Majesty (*Kalimat al-Jalala*). Some realized masters said, in a state: "I am Allah." And some Sufis also said it from two different stations, and there is a vast difference between the station of the meaning and the station of the letter that was found for him. So the Exalted countered the letter with the letter: "I seek refuge in Your pleasure from Your wrath," and countered the meaning with the meaning: "And I seek refuge in You from You." This is the ultimate gnosis (*ma‘rifa*).

### [Conclusion: The Difference Between Allah and Ar-Rahman]

Perhaps you distinguish between *Allah* and *Ar-Rahman* because of what occurs in the Qur'an: His saying, the Exalted: <<اعْبُدُوا اللَّهَ>> (Worship Allah), and they did not say, "And what is Allah?" But when it was said to them: <<اسْجُدُوا لِلرَّحْمَٰنِ قَالُوا وَمَا الرَّحْمَٰنُ>> (Prostrate to the All-Merciful, they said: And what is the All-Merciful?). For this reason, the adjective (*na‘t*) was preferred over the appositive (*badal*) by some, while others preferred the appositive, due to His saying, the Exalted: <<قُلِ ادْعُوا اللَّهَ أَوِ ادْعُوا الرَّحْمَٰنَ أَيًّا مَّا تَدْعُوا فَلَهُ الْأَسْمَاءُ الْحُسْنَىٰ>> (Say: Call upon Allah or call upon the All-Merciful. Whichever you call upon—to Him belong the Most Beautiful Names). He made them both for the Essence. The Arabs did not deny the word *Allah*, for they were the ones who said: <<مَا نَعْبُدُهُمْ إِلَّا لِيُقَرِّبُونَا إِلَى اللَّهِ زُلْفَىٰ>> (We only worship them that they may bring us nearer to Allah in proximity). So they knew Him. But since *Ar-Rahman* implies derivation from mercy (*al-rahma*), which is an Attribute existing in them, they feared that the Worshipped One indicated to them might be of their own kind. So they denied it and said, "And what is the All-Merciful?" because it is not a condition for every utterance that its meaning be understood. For this reason, He said: <<قُلِ ادْعُوا اللَّهَ أَوِ ادْعُوا الرَّحْمَٰنَ>>, since both terms refer back to a single Essence. That is the reality of the servant, and the Creator is purified from the perception of imagination and encompassing knowledge of Him; He is exalted far above that.

### [Continuation: Concerning Ar-Rahim in the Basmala]

Concerning *Ar-Rahim* (الرَّحِيمِ) in the *Basmala*: *Ar-Rahim* is the Attribute of Muhammad (peace be upon him). The Exalted said: <<بِالْمُؤْمِنِينَ رَءُوفٌ رَّحِيمٌ>> (To the believers, compassionate and Especially Merciful). By him is the perfection of Existence (الوجود), and by *Ar-Rahim* the *Basmala* is completed, and by its completion, the World is completed in creation and origination. He (peace be upon him) was the beginning of the World’s existence intellectually and spiritually: "When were you a prophet?" He said: "While Adam was between water and clay." So by him, Existence began inwardly, and by him, the station was sealed outwardly in the world of inscription, when he said: "There is no messenger after me, nor prophet." Thus, *Ar-Rahim* is Muhammad (peace be upon him), and *Bismi* (بِسْمِ) is our father Adam—I mean in the station of the beginning and the end of the matter. This is because Adam (peace be upon him) is the bearer of the Names. The Exalted said: <<وَعَلَّمَ آدَمَ الْأَسْمَاءَ كُلَّهَا>> (And He taught Adam all the Names). And Muhammad (peace be upon him) is the bearer of the meanings of those Names that Adam bore (peace be upon them both), which are the Words (*al-Kalim*).

The Prophet (peace be upon him) said: "I have been given the comprehensive Words (*jawami‘ al-kalim*)."

And the one who praises himself is more empowered and complete than the one who is praised by others, like Yahya and Isa (peace be upon them). Whoever attains the Essence (الذات), the Names are under his rule. But it is not the case that whoever attains the Names has the Named One attained by him. By this, the Companions excelled us, for they attained the Essence, while we attained the Name. When we observed the Name with the same observance they gave to the Essence, our reward was multiplied, due to the sorrow of absence (*al-ghayba*) that they did not experience. Thus, the multiplication was upon multiplication. We are the brethren, and they are the Companions. He (peace be upon him) longs for us. How happy he is to meet one of us! How could he not be happy when one who longed for him has come to him? Can his honor, goodness, and attention be measured? The worker among us receives the reward of fifty of those who perform the work of his Companions—not the Companions themselves, but their likes. That is His saying: "Rather, from among you." So strive and exert yourselves until they know that they left behind men who, had they reached his time, would not have surpassed them. From here comes the recompense. And Allah is the Helper.

### [Note: The Bearers of the Encompassing Throne in the Basmala]

You should know that *Bismillah ar-Rahman ar-Rahim* consists of four words that have four meanings, making eight. These are the bearers of the Encompassing Throne (*hamalat al-‘Arsh al-Muhit*). Here, they are the bearers from one perspective and the Throne from another. So look and extract from your essence for your essence.

### [Note: The Mīm of Bismi and the Mīm of Ar-Rahim]

Then we found the *Mīm* of *Bismi*, which is Adam (peace be upon him), showing perspiration (*mu‘arraqan*), and we found the *Mīm* of *Ar-Rahim*, which is Muhammad (peace be upon him), showing perspiration. We knew that the substance of the *Mīm* of Adam (peace be upon him) was for the existence of the world of composition, since he was not sent as a messenger. And we knew that the substance of the *Mīm* of Muhammad (peace be upon him) was for the existence of the address generally, just as Adam was general for us. For this reason, they both extended.

### [Information: The Days of the Lord and the Basmala]

Our Master, who does not speak from caprice, said: "If my community is righteous, it has one day, and if it is corrupt, it has half a day." The Day is Lordly (*Rabbani*), for the Days of the Lord are every day of a thousand years of what we count, unlike the Days of Allah and the Days of the Ascending Stairways (*Dhi al-Ma‘arij*), for these days have a larger sphere than the Days of the Lord. Their mention will come, if Allah wills, inside the Book in the knowledge of the times. The righteousness of the community is by its looking toward him (peace be upon him), and its corruption is by its turning away from him. We found that *Bismillah ar-Rahman ar-Rahim* contains a thousand meanings, and each meaning is only attained after the passing of a year (*hawl*). The attainment of these meanings contained in *Bismillah ar-Rahman ar-Rahim* is necessary, because it only appeared to give its meaning. Thus, a full thousand years are necessary for this community. It is in the first cycle of the Balance (*al-Mizan*), and its duration is six thousand verified spiritual years. For this reason, Divine sciences (*al-‘ulum al-Ilahiyya*) appeared in it that did not appear in other communities. The cycle that passed was earthly (*turabiyya*), so the limit of their knowledge was in natures (*al-taba’i‘*), and the divinely oriented among them were very few strangers, whose essence hardly appeared. Furthermore, the divinely oriented among them were necessarily mixed with nature, whereas the divinely oriented among us are pure and unmixed, and the ruling of nature has no way over them.

### [Key: The Alif of Essence and the Alif of Knowledge in Ar-Rahman]

Then we found two *Alif*s in *Allah* and *Ar-Rahman*: the *Alif* of the Essence (ألف الذات) and the *Alif* of Knowledge (ألف العلم). The *Alif* of the Essence is hidden, and the *Alif* of Knowledge is manifest, so that the Attribute may manifest to the World. Also, it was hidden in *Allah* and did not appear to remove ambiguity in the script between *Allah* (الله) and *al-Lāh* (اللاه). We found one *Alif* in *Bismi*, which is Adam (peace be upon him), hidden for the manifestation of the *Bā’*. We found one *Alif* in *Ar-Rahim*, which is Muhammad (peace be upon him), manifest, and it is the *Alif* of Knowledge. The Soul (*Nafs*) of our Master Muhammad (peace be upon him) is the Essence (الذات). The *Alif* was hidden in Adam (peace be upon him) because he was not sent as a messenger to anyone, so there was no need for the manifestation of the Attribute. It appeared in our Master Muhammad (peace be upon him) because he was sent as a messenger, so he sought support and was given the *Alif*, by which he appeared. Then we found that the *Bā’* of *Bismi* acted upon the *Mīm* of *Ar-Rahim*. The action of Adam upon Muhammad (peace be upon him) was the existence of composition. In *Allah*, the action was due to a calling cause, and in *Ar-Rahman*, the action was due to a called cause. Since we saw that the end is nobler than the beginning, we said: "Whoever knows himself knows his Lord," and the Name is a ladder to the Named. When we knew that the Spirit of *Ar-Rahim* acted upon the Spirit of *Bismi*—since he was a prophet while Adam was between water and clay, and without them both, Adam would not have been named—we knew that *Bismi* is *Ar-Rahim*, since nothing acts except from itself, not from another. Thus, the end and the beginning, polytheism (*al-shirk*) and Unity (*al-tawhid*), vanished, and the glory of Union (*al-Ittihad*) and its sovereignty appeared. Muhammad is for Gathering (الجمع), and Adam is for Separation (التفريق).

### [Clarification: The Letters of Ar-Rahim and their Hidden Significance]

The proof that the Alif in His saying *Al-Rahim* (The Merciful) is the Alif of Knowledge (ألف العلم) is His saying: <<nor five, except He is their sixth.>> And in the Alif of *Bism* (In the Name), [the proof is] <<nor three men in secret conference, but He is their fourth.>> Thus, the Alif is the Alif, and there is nothing less than that—which is the inner reality (باطن) of Unity (التوحيد)—nor more than that—which is its outer manifestation (ظاهر).

Then the Alif was concealed in Adam, from *Bism*, because he was the first Existent (أول موجود) and had no rival claiming his station (مقام). So, by his Essence (ذات), he indicated immediately the Existence (وجود) of his Originator (موجده), as he was the opening of our existence. This is because when he contemplated his existence, two matters presented themselves: Did an Existent without beginning bring him into being, or did he bring himself into being? It is impossible that he brought himself into being, because he must either bring himself into being while he is already existent, or bring himself into being while he is non-existent (معدوم). If he was existent, what brought him into being? If he was non-existent, how could he effect creation (إيجاد) while being non-existence? Therefore, it remained only that another brought him into being, and that is the Alif. For this reason, the letter *Sin* was quiescent (ساكنة), representing non-existence (العدم), and the letter *Mim* was vocalized (متحركة), representing the moment of affirmation (أوان الإيجاب).

Since he indicated Him immediately, the Alif was concealed due to the strength of the indication. It appeared in *Al-Rahim* (The Merciful) due to the weakness of the indication for Muhammad (peace be upon him), because of the existence of a rival. Thus, He supported him with the Alif. *Al-Rahim* therefore became Muhammad, and the Alif within it is The Real (الحق) supporting him from His Name, The Manifest (الظاهر). The Exalted said: <<And they became manifest (ظاهرين)>>. So He said: "Say, 'There is no god but Allah, and I am His Messenger.'" Whoever believes in its mere wording (لفظه) has not escaped the bondage (رق) of polytheism (الشرك), though he is among the people of Paradise. But whoever believes in its meaning (معناه) is integrated into the thread of Unity (سلك التوحيد), and the Eighth Paradise is confirmed for him. He is among those who believed in his own self (نفسه), and thus he was not weighed against others, for equality (السوية) has occurred, and the state of being chosen (الاصطفائية) has united in totality, though the message (رسالة) differed.

### The Dots of the Basmala and their Esoteric Significance

We find that *Bism* (In the Name) has one dot, and *Al-Rahman* (The Compassionate) likewise, but *Al-Rahim* (The Merciful) has two dots. *Allah* is solid (مصمت) [without dots in its essential form], so dots are not found in *Allah* because it refers to the Essence (الذات). They are found in the remaining [letters/words] because they are the locus of the Attributes (محل الصفات).

The dot was singular in the *Bism* of Adam because he was an individual (فرد) and not a Messenger (مرسل). It was singular in *Al-Rahman* because it is Adam, who is established upon the Throne (عرش) of composite existents (الكائنات المركبات).

The discussion remains concerning the two dots of *Al-Rahim* (The Merciful) along with the appearance of the Alif. The letter *Ya* (ي) represents the Ten Nights, the two dots represent the Even (الشفع), and the Alif represents the Odd (الوتر). The Name in its entirety is the Dawn (الفجر), and its inner meaning (معناه الباطن) is the Presence of Power (الجبروتي), and <<the night when it departs>> is the Presence of Dominion (الغيب الملكوتي).

The arrangement of the two dots is: one near the *Mim* and the second near the Alif. The *Mim* is the existence (وجود) of the world to whom [the Prophet] was sent. The dot near the *Mim* is Abu Bakr (may Allah be pleased with him), and the dot near the Alif is Muhammad (peace be upon him). The letter *Ya* (ي) has arched over them like the cave, <<when he said to his companion, 'Do not grieve; indeed, Allah is with us.'>> For [Abu Bakr] stood firm with his sincerity (صدق), while Muhammad (peace be upon him) stood firm with The Real (الحق) in the state (حال) he was in at that time. Thus, [Muhammad] is the Wise One (الحكيم), like his action on the Day of Badr in supplication and insistence. Abu Bakr was the companion (صاحب) in that. For the Wise One gives every station (موطن) its due. Since it is not valid for two sincere ones (صادقين) to stand together in that way, Abu Bakr did not stand in the state (حال) of the Prophet (peace be upon him), but remained firm with his sincerity to him. If the Prophet (peace be upon him) had been absent from that station and Abu Bakr had been present, he would have stood in the station (مقام) where the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) was established, because there is none higher than him to veil him from it. He would have been the sincere one (صادق) and the wise one (حكيم) of that time, and everything else would have been under his rule.

When the dot of Abu Bakr looked upon the seekers (الطالبين), he felt sorrow for them, so he manifested severity, and sincerity (الصدق) prevailed, and he said, "Do not grieve," due to the effect of that sorrow, <<Indeed, Allah is with us,>> as you informed us. Even if a rival claims that Muhammad was the speaker, we do not mind, because his station (مقام) (peace be upon him) was the combination of Gathering (الجمع) and Separation (التفرقة) simultaneously. He knew of Abu Bakr's sorrow, and he looked toward the Alif, so he was supported, and he knew that his command would continue until the Day of Resurrection. He said, "Do not grieve; indeed, Allah is with us." This is the noblest station (مقام) one can reach: "I did not see a thing except that I saw Allah before it"—a Bakri witnessing (شهود بكري) and a Muhammadan inheritance (وراثة محمدية). He addressed the people with [the saying]: "Whoever knows his self knows his Lord." This is His saying, the Exalted, informing about his Lord, the Exalted: <<No! Indeed, my Lord is with me; He will guide me.>> In our view, this statement was only for Abu Bakr (may Allah be pleased with him), and we are supported by the saying of the Prophet (peace be upon him): "If I were to take a close friend (Khalil), I would have taken Abu Bakr as a close friend!" Thus, the Prophet (peace be upon him) is not a companion (مصاحب) [in the sense of equality], but some of them are companions to each other, and they are his helpers and supporters. Understand our allusion, and you will be guided to the straight path.

### The Two Dots and the Two Feet

The two dots of *Al-Rahim* (The Merciful) are the place of the two feet, which is one aspect of the removal of the sandals: the Command (الأمر) and the Prohibition (النهي). The Alif is the Blessed Night (الليلة المباركة), which is the Unseen (غيب) of Muhammad (peace be upon him). Then, separation (فرق) occurred within it into Command and Prohibition, which is His saying: <<In which every wise matter is determined.>> This [determination] is the Footstool (الكرسي). The letter *Ha* (ح) is the Throne (العرش), the *Mim* (م) is what it encompasses, the Alif (ا) is the limit of the Established One (حد المستوي), the *Ra* (ر) is the screeching of the Pen (صريف القلم), and the *Nun* (ن) is the inkwell within the *Lam* (ل). So, what was and what will be was written on the parchment of the Tablet of *Al-Rahim* (The Merciful), which is the Preserved Tablet (اللوح المحفوظ), expressed as "everything" in the Glorious Book, by way of allusion (إشارة) and notification (تنبيه). The Exalted said: <<And We wrote for him on the tablets [something] of everything>>—which is the Preserved Tablet—<<an instruction and a detailed explanation for everything>>—which is the comprehensive Preserved Tablet. This is an expression of the Prophet (peace be upon him) in his saying: "I have been given the comprehensive words (جوامع الكلم)." Instruction and detailed explanation (موعظة وتفصيلا): these are the two dots of Command and Prohibition for everything, which is the Unseen of Muhammad (the Alif) alluded to by the Blessed Night.

### The Seven Stars in Al-Rahim

The Alif is for Knowledge (العلم), and it is the Established One (المستوي). The *Lam* (ل) is for Will (الإرادة), and it is the *Nun* (ن), meaning the inkwell. The *Ra* (ر) is for Power (القدرة), and it is the Pen (القلم). The *Ha* (ح) is for the Throne (العرش). The *Ya* (ي) is for the Footstool (الكرسي). The head of the *Mim* (م) is for the Heaven, and its tail is for the Earth. These are seven stars (أنجم). One star swims in the sphere of the body (الجسم), one star in the sphere of the rational soul (النفس الناطقة), one star in the sphere of the secret of the soul (سر النفس), which is Sincerity (الصديقية), one star in the sphere of the heart (القلب), one star in the sphere of the Intellect (العقل), and one star in the sphere of the Spirit (الروح). So, unlock what we have sealed, for in what we have established is the key to what we have concealed. Seek, and you shall find, God willing. Thus, *Bismillahi al-Rahmani al-Rahim* (In the Name of Allah, the Compassionate, the Merciful), even if it is manifold, is one when realized from a certain perspective.

### A Section on the Secrets of the Mother of the Quran via a Special Path

It is the Opening of the Book (فاتحة الكتاب), the Seven Oft-Repeated Verses (السبع المثاني), the Glorious Quran (القرآن العظيم), and the Sufficient One (الكافية). The *Basmala* is a verse from it. It encompasses the Lord (الرب) and the servant (العبد). We have a poem concerning its division:

> The two lights have a rising in the heart, so
> In the Surah of Praise, a third appears for them.
> The full moon is effacement, and the sun of the Essence is shining;
> Were it not for the rising, you would find it non-existence (عدما).
> These stars are rising on the eastern horizon,
> While the full moon adheres to the intellectual west.
> If it manifests, neither star nor moon
> Appears drawn in the celestial sphere.

### The Book from the Perspective of Allusion

It is the Opening of the Book (فاتحة الكتاب) because the Book, by way of allusion (إشارة), is an expression of the First Originator (المبدع الأول). The Book encompasses the Opening and other things because it originates from it. The name *Al-Fatiha* is valid for it because it is the first thing with which the Book of Existence (كتاب الوجود) was opened. It is an expression of the Transcendent Archetype (المثل المنزه) in <<There is nothing like unto Him (لَيْسَ كَمِثْلِهِ شَيْ‏ءٌ)>>, such that the *Kaf* (ك) [in *ka-mithlihi*] is the very Attribute (عين الصفة). When He brought into existence the Archetype (المثل), which is the Opening, He brought the Book into existence after it and made [the Opening] its key. Reflect upon this.

It is the Mother of the Quran (أم القرآن) because the mother (الأم) is the locus of creation (محل الإيجاد), the existent within it is the Quran, and the Originator (الموجد) is the active agent in the mother. The Mother is the Universal Comprehensive Reality (الجامعة الكلية). It is the Mother of the Book (أم الكتاب) which is with Him, in His saying, the Exalted: <<and with Him is the Mother of the Book (أُمُّ الْكِتابِ)>>. Look at Jesus and Mary (peace be upon them). The agent of creation (فاعل الإيجاد) will reveal to you the opposite of what appears to your senses. The Mother (الأم) is Jesus, and the Son, who is the Book of the Divine Presence (الكتاب العندي) or the Quran, is Mary (peace be upon them). Understand this.

Likewise, the Spirit (الروح) coupled with the Soul (النفس) through the mediation of the Intellect (العقل). Thus, the Soul became the sensory locus of creation (محل الإيجاد حسا), and the Spirit came to it only from the Soul. So, the Soul is the Father. This Soul is the Inscribed Book (الكتاب المرقوم) due to the penetration of the writing. What the Pen inscribed in the Mother appeared in the Son, and that is the Quran manifested in the world of witnessing (عالم الشهادة). The Mother is also an expression of the existence of the Archetype (وجود المثل), the locus of secrets (محل الأسرار). It is the Spread Parchment (الرق المنشور) in which the Inscribed Book (الكتاب المسطور) is deposited, containing those Divine Secrets (الأسرار الإلهية).

The Book here is higher than the Opening, for the Opening is the guide (دليل) to the Book and its signified (مدلول). The honor of the guide is according to what it signifies. Consider if it were a key to the opposite of the known Book—assuming an opposite could be hypothesized—the guide would be debased due to the baseness of the signified. For this reason, the Prophet (peace be upon him) alluded that one should not travel with the *Mushaf* (physical copy of the Quran) to the land of the enemy, due to the indication of those letters toward the Speech of Allah (كلام الله), since The Real (الحق) has named it the Speech of Allah. However, letters and words, when not intended to signify the Speech of Allah, may be traveled with to the land of the enemy and taken into places of impurity and the like. And the Unveiling (الكشف)...

### The Two Presences of Gathering and Separation in Al-Fatiha

It is the Seven Oft-Repeated Verses (السبع المثاني) and the Glorious Quran (القرآن العظيم). The Attributes (الصفات) appeared in Existence (الوجود) in one and one: a Presence of Singularity (حضرة تفرد) and a Presence of Gathering (حضرة تجمع). From the *Basmala* up to *al-Din* (Day of Judgment) is Singularity (إفراد), and likewise from *Ihdina* (Guide us) up to *al-Dallin* (the astray). And His saying <<You alone we worship and You alone we ask for help>> encompasses [both].

Allah, the Exalted, said: "I have divided the prayer between Myself and My servant into two halves: half is for Me, and half is for My servant, and My servant shall have what he asks for." To you belongs the asking, and from Him comes the giving, just as to Him belongs the asking through Command and Prohibition, and to you belongs the compliance.

The servant says: <<All praise is due to Allah, Lord of the worlds.>> Allah says: "My servant has praised Me." The servant says: <<The Compassionate, the Merciful.>> Allah says: "My servant has extolled Me." The servant says: <<Master (Malik) of the Day of Recompense.>> Allah says: "My servant has glorified Me," and sometimes He says: "My servant has entrusted the matter to Me." This is Divine Singularity (إفراد إلهي).

In another narration, the servant says: *Bismillahi al-Rahmani al-Rahim*. Allah says: "My servant has remembered Me." Then He says: The servant says: <<You alone we worship and You alone we ask for help.>> Allah says: "This is between Me and My servant, and My servant shall have what he asks for." The *Ma* (ما) [in *ma sa'al*] is the giving. And *Iyyaka* (You alone) in both places is attached to the Divine Singularity. The servant says: <<Guide us to the straight path—the path of those upon whom You have bestowed favor, not of those who have evoked [Your] anger or of those who are astray.>> These are for My servant. This is the Servanthood Singularity (الإفراد العبدي) that is worshipped. "And My servant shall have what he asks for." He asked for a worshipped one (مألوه), not a god (إلها). Thus, only two Presences (حضرات) remain, and the Seven Oft-Repeated Verses (المثاني) are confirmed.

So, [the Fatiha] appeared in The Real (الحق) as Existence (وجود) and in the Universal Servant (العبد الكلي) as creation (إيجاد). He described Himself with them, and there was no Existent (موجود) other than Him in the Cloud (*Al-Ama'*). Then He described His servant with them when He made him His vicegerent (استخلفه). For this reason, they fell prostrate to him, due to the establishment of the Form (الصورة). The Separation (الفرق) occurred from the place of the two feet until the Day of Resurrection. The Glorious Quran (القرآن العظيم) is the Gathering (الجمع) and Existence (الوجود), which is His separation from you and your gathering with Him. It is nothing but His saying: <<You alone we worship and You alone we ask for help,>> and that is sufficient. <<And Allah speaks the truth, and He guides to the way.>>

### An Event: *Al-Hamdu Lillahi* via the Path of Secrets

The Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) sent Uthman (may Allah be pleased with him) to me, commanding me to speak in a dream after my intercession (شفاعتي) for my community had occurred, and all were saved from the bondage of destruction. The highest pulpit (المنبر الأسنى) was brought near, and I ascended it by the supreme Muhammadan high permission (الأذن العالي المحمدي الأسمى), restricting myself specifically to the phrase *Al-Hamdu Lillahi* (All praise is due to Allah). Divine support (التأييد) descended, and the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) was seated to the right of the pulpit.

The servant said, after reciting, praising, extolling, and saying the *Basmala*: The Reality of Praise (حقيقة الحمد) is the sanctified, transcendent servant (العبد المقدس المنزه) *Lillahi* (to Allah), alluding to the Pre-Eternal Essence (الذات الأزلية). This is the station (مقام) of the separation of the servant's existence from the God's existence. Then He veiled him from his own existence by His Pre-Eternal Existence and connected him to Him, so He said *Lillahi* (to Allah). The *Lam* (ل) that enters upon the word *Allah* and causes it to be in the genitive case (الخافضة له) is the reality of the Worshipped One (حقيقة المألوه) in the chapter of humility and lowliness. It is one of the particles of meaning (حروف المعاني), not one of the letters of the alphabet (حروف الهجاء). Then the Glorified One placed it before His own Name, honoring it, emphasizing it, and transcending its knowledge of itself, confirming the Prophet's (peace be upon him) precedence of it in his saying: "Whoever knows his self knows his Lord."

So, He gave precedence to the knowledge of the self over the knowledge of the Lord. Then [the *Lam*] acted upon the Name *Allah* to realize the connection (الاتصال) and establish it in the station. Since [the servant] was in the station of connection (الوصلة), it might be imagined that the Praise (الحمد) was other than the *Lam*. So the servant put [the *Dal* of *Al-Hamd*] in the genitive case, following the movement of the *Lam*. Thus, *Al-Hamdu Lillahi* was recited with the *Dal* in the genitive case. The word *Al-Hamd* was thus a substitute for the *Lam*, a substitution of one thing for another, yet both belong to a single essence (عين واحدة). The Praise is the existence of the *Lam*, and the *Lam* is the Praise. If they are one thing, then the Praise is in the station of connection (الوصلة) with Allah, because it is the very essence of the *Lam*. Thus, it was meaning, just as the *Lam* was word and meaning.

Then, the reality of the genitive case (الخفض) in it is the affirmation of servanthood (العبودية). Then, sometimes He annihilates it from itself (يفنيها عن نفسها) with a total annihilation (فناء كليا) to raise it to the highest station (المقام الأعلى) in Primordiality (الأولية). Then He preserves its reality in Finality (الآخرية), so He says *Al-Hamdu Lillahu* (with the *Lam* in the nominative case), following the movement of the *Dal*. This confirms that the Praise is the *Lam*, which is expressed as the cloak (*Rida'*) and the garment (*Thawb*), as it is the locus of the Attributes (محل الصفات) and the separation of the Gathering (افتراق الجمع). The utmost knowledge of the servants is to reach it, if they reach it, and attach [the rest] beyond all that, or rather, along with all that.

When He raised it by annihilating it from itself initially, He wished to inform it, even in its annihilation, that it had not departed from its station. So He made it the agent (عاملة) and made its nominative case accidental (عارضا) in relation to The Real (الحق). He kept the *Ha* (ه) [of *Allahu*] in the genitive case, indicating the existence of the *Lam* in the station of the lowliness of servanthood (خفض العبودة). For this reason, the middle *Lam* is doubled with the word *La* (لا), meaning the Essence of The Real (ذات الحق) is not the essence of the servant, but rather it is the reality of the Archetype (حقيقة المثل) for the manifestation of the Form (تجلى الصورة). Then the *Ha* (ه) refers back to the *Lam* because it is its object (معمولها). If the *Ha* were an allusion to the Essence of The Real, the *Lam* would not act upon it; rather, He is the Agent (العامل) in everything. If the *Lam* is the very Praise, and the *Ha* is the object of the *Lam*, then the *Ha* is the *Lam*. And the *Lam* was the Praise. Thus, the *Ha* is the Praise, without addition.

We have said that the doubled *Lam* is for the negation of the united Gathering (الجمع المتحد), which is the place of separation (الفصل). The implication of this discourse is that the Praise (*Al-Hamd*) is His saying *Lillahi* (to Allah), and His saying *Lillahi* is His saying *Al-Hamd*. The utmost achievement of the servant is that he praised his own self (نفسه) which he saw in the mirror, for the originated (المحدث) has no capacity to bear the Eternal (القديم). So, He originated the Archetype (المثل) upon the Form (الصورة), and the one who affirms Unity (الموحد) became a mirror. When the form of the Archetype was manifested in the mirror of the Essence (مرآة الذات), He said to it when it perceived the Essence and sneezed, thereby distinguishing itself: "Praise the One you saw." So it praised itself and said, *Al-Hamdu Lillahi*. He said to it: "May your Lord have mercy on you, O Adam. For this I created you."

His Mercy preceded His Wrath. For this reason, following His saying <<All praise is due to Allah, Lord of the worlds... The Compassionate, the Merciful,>> He put Mercy first. Then He said <<not of those who have evoked [Your] anger,>> thus delaying His Wrath. Mercy preceded Wrath at the very opening of Existence (افتتاح الوجود). Mercy preceded [punishment for] Adam before the penalty for eating from the tree, and then He showed mercy afterwards. Thus, two Mercies came, between them a Wrath. The two Mercies seek to blend because they are two archetypes (مثلان). This one joined with that one, and the Wrath between them vanished, as some have said concerning two eases between which is a hardship:

> If the matter becomes difficult for you,
> Reflect upon *Alam Nashrah* (Did We not expand?).
> For hardship is between two eases,
> When you remember it, rejoice.

Mercy (الرحمة) is an expression of the First Existent (الموجود الأول), expressed as the Sought One (المطلوب). Those who have evoked [His] anger (المغضوب عليهم) are the commanding soul (النفس الأمارة), and the astray (الضالون) are the world of composition (عالم التركيب), as long as [the soul] is subject to anger. For the Creator (الباري) is transcendent beyond being transcended, since there is no other, and no Existent except Him. For this reason, [the Prophet] (peace be upon him) alluded with his saying: "The believer is the mirror of his brother." Due to the existence of the Form (الصورة) in its perfection, for it is the locus of Gnosis (محل المعرفة) and the means of connection. Had He brought him into existence upon a form other than that, he would have been inanimate. So, praise be to Allah, who bestowed favor upon the Gnostics (العارفين) who stand with Him, with the provisions of Divine Care (مواد العناية), eternally and perpetually.

### A Note: *Al-Hamdu Lillahi* and *Al-Hamdu Billahi* via the Path of Secrets

The *Lam* (ل) annihilates the trace (الرسم), just as the *Ba* (ب) preserves it. For this reason, Abu al-Abbas ibn al-Arif said: "The scholars are for Me, and the Gnostics are by Me." He established the highest station (المقام الأعلى) for the *Lam*, for he said in his discourse: "And the Gnostics are by means of spiritual aspiration (الهمم)." Then, concerning the *Lam*, he said: "And The Real (الحق) is beyond all that." Then, he added a further notification, not content with this alone, saying: "And the spiritual aspirations are for reaching [Him], and the aspiration is for the *Ba*-Gnostics." And concerning the *Lam*-Scholars, he said: "The Real is only made manifest when the trace (الرسم) vanishes." This is the station of the *Lam*: the annihilation of the trace (فناء الرسم).

Thus, *Al-Hamdu Lillahi* is higher than *Al-Hamdu Billahi*. For *Al-Hamdu Billahi* preserves you, while *Al-Hamdu Lillahi* annihilates you (يفنيك). When the scholar (العالم) says *Al-Hamdu Lillahi*, he means: "There is no one who praises Allah except Him." It is more fitting, then, that there is no one praised other than Him. The common people (العامة) say *Al-Hamdu Lillahi*, meaning: "There is no one praised except Allah," and they are the praisers. They share the form of the utterance. The scholars annihilated the created praisers and the praised ones, while the common people annihilated the praised ones from creation specifically. As for the Gnostics (العارفون), they cannot say *Al-Hamdu Lillahi* except like the common people. Rather, their station is *Al-Hamdu Billahi* due to the subsistence (بقاء) of their souls (نفوسهم) with them. Verify this chapter, for it is from the core of Gnosis (لباب المعرفة).

### A Section on His Saying: Lord of the Worlds, The Compassionate, The Merciful

By His saying, *Lord of the worlds* (رَبِّ الْعالَمِينَ), He established the Presence of Lordship (حضرة الربوبية) within us and in our hearts. This is the station of the Gnostic (مقام العارف) and the firm footing of the soul (رسوخ قدم النفس), which is the locus of the Attribute (موضع الصفة). For our saying *Lillahi* (to Allah) is the essentiality of the witnessing (ذاتية المشهد), the high place of union (عالية المتحد). Then He followed it with His saying *Lord of the worlds*, meaning their commander and nourisher. The worlds (العالمين) are an expression for everything other than Allah.

Nurturing (*Tarbiyya*) is divided into two types: nurturing through mediation (واسطة) and nurturing without mediation. As for the Word (الكلمة), mediation is absolutely inconceivable in its regard. As for what is below it, mediation is necessary. Then, nurturing through mediation is divided into two types: praiseworthy and blameworthy. From the Eternal (القديم) to the Soul (النفس)—and the Soul is included in the definition—there is only the specifically defined. As for the blameworthy and the praiseworthy, they extend from the Soul to the sensory world (عالم الحس). Thus, the Soul was a locus capable of receiving change (التغيير) and purification (التطهير).

### The Word: Repository of Secrets and Wisdoms

We say that when Allah, the Exalted, brought the Word (الكلمة)—expressed as the Universal Spirit (الروح الكلي)—into existence through origination (*Ibda'*), He brought it into existence in the station of ignorance (مقام الجهل) and the locus of negation (محل السلب), meaning He blinded it from seeing itself. Thus, it remained unaware of where it originated or how it originated. The nourishment (الغذاء) that was the cause of its life and subsistence (بقائه) was within it, yet it did not know. So, Allah stirred its spiritual aspiration (همته) to seek what was with Him, though it did not know that it was with Him. It began the journey with its aspiration. The Real (الحق), the Exalted, made it witness His Essence (ذاته), so it became tranquil and knew that what it sought had always been described [by Him].

Ibrahim ibn Mas'ud al-Ilbiri said:
> A person may journey for what he seeks,
> While the cause of what is sought is within the traveler.

It knew the secrets (الأسرار) and wisdoms (الحكم) that Allah had deposited within it. Its originated nature (حدوثه) was confirmed to it, and it knew its Essence (ذاته) with a comprehensive Gnosis (معرفة إحاطية). That Gnosis became a specific nourishment (غذاء معينا) by which it sustained itself, and its life endured without end. At that Most Holy Theophany (التجلي الأقدس), He said to it: "What is My Name with you?" It replied: "You are my Lord (ربي)." It only knew Him in the Presence of Lordship (حضرة الربوبية). The Eternal (القديم) is singular in Divinity (الألوهية), for none knows Him but Him.

The Glorified One said to it: "You are My nurtured one (مربوبي), and I am your Lord. I have given you My Names and My Attributes (صفاتي). Whoever sees you sees Me, whoever obeys you obeys Me, whoever knows you knows Me, and whoever is ignorant of you is ignorant of Me. The utmost achievement of those below you is to reach the knowledge of their own souls (نفوسهم) through you. The utmost of their knowledge of Me is the knowledge of My Existence (وجودك), not My modality (كيفيتك). Likewise, you, with Me, do not exceed the knowledge of your own self, nor do you see other than yourself. You do not attain Knowledge (العلم) of Me except from the perspective of Existence. If you were to encompass Me with knowledge, you would be Me, and I would be encompassed by you, and My I-ness (أنيتي) would be your I-ness, but your I-ness is not My I-ness. So, I supply you with the Divine Secrets (الأسرار الإلهية) and nurture you with them. You find them placed within you, and thus you know them. I have veiled you from knowing the modality of My supply to you, for you lack the capacity to bear the witnessing (مشاهدتها) of it. If you knew it, the I-ness would unite, and the union of I-ness is impossible. Therefore, your witnessing of that is impossible. Can the I-ness of the composite (المركب) revert to the I-ness of the simple (البسيط)? There is no way to overturn the realities (قلب الحقائق). Know that those below you are subject to your governance, just as you are subject to My governance. You are My garment, My cloak, and My covering."

### The Tragedy of the Spirit in Heaven

The Spirit (الروح) said to Him: "My Lord, I heard You mention that I have a dominion (ملك). Where is it?" So, He extracted the Soul (النفس) for him from it—which is the effect of the emanation (المفعول عن الانبعاث). He said: "This is part of Me, and I am the whole of it, just as I am from you, but you are not from Me." He said: "You have spoken the truth, O My Spirit." [The Spirit] said: "By You I was conceived, O my Lord. You nurtured me and veiled from me the secret of supply (سر الإمداد) and nurturing, and You were singular in possessing it. So, make my supply veiled from this dominion (ملك) so that it remains ignorant of me, just as I was ignorant of You."

So, He created in the Soul the attribute of acceptance (القبول) and need (الافتقار), and He made the Intellect (العقل) the vizier (وزير) to the Holy Spirit (الروح المقدس). Then He showed the Spirit to the Soul. He said to it: "Who am I?" It said: "My Lord, by You is my life, and by You is my subsistence (بقائي)." The Spirit became lost in its dominion and stood in it in the station of its Lord over it, imagining that this was the very supply itself. The Real (الحق) wished to inform it that the matter was contrary to what it imagined, and that if He had given it the secret of supply as it requested, Divinity (الألوهية) would not have been singular in anything apart from it, and the I-ness would have united.

When He willed this, He created Caprice (الهوى) in opposition to [the Spirit], and He created Desire (الشهوة) in opposition to the Intellect, making it the vizier to Caprice. He placed in the Soul the capacity for accepting all incoming influences (القبول لجميع الواردات) generally. Thus, the Soul found itself between two powerful lords, each having a great vizier. This one continually calls to it, and that one calls to it, and all are from Allah. The Exalted said: <<Say, "All is from Allah.">> and <<We extend to all—to these and to those—from the gift of your Lord.>> For this reason, the Soul was the locus of change and purification. The Exalted said: <<and inspired it [with discernment of] its wickedness and its righteousness,>> following His saying: <<And [by] the soul and He who proportioned it.>> If it answers the caller of Caprice (الهوى), there is change. If it answers the caller of the Spirit (الروح), there is purification, both legally and in terms of Unity (توحيدا). When the Spirit saw that it called and heard no answer, it said: "What prevented my dominion from answering me?" The vizier (the Intellect) said to him: "Opposite you is an obeyed king of great authority called Caprice (الهوى). His gift is immediate: the world in its entirety. He spread out his presence for it and called it, and it answered him." So the Spirit returned to Allah, the Exalted, with a complaint, and its servanthood (عبوديته) was confirmed. That was the intended purpose.

### Lords and Nurtured Ones in Various Worlds

The lords (الأرباب) and the nurtured ones (المربوبون) descended, each according to his station (مقام) and measure. The separated world of witnessing (عالم الشهادة المنفصل) has the world of address (عالم الخطاب) as its lord. The connected world of witnessing (عالم الشهادة المتصل) has the world of Power (عالم الجبروت) as its lord. The world of Power has the world of Dominion (عالم الملكوت) as its lord. The world of Dominion has the Word (الكلمة) as its lord. And the Lord of the Word is the Lord of all, the One, the Eternal Refuge (الصمد).

We have fully elaborated on this chapter in our book titled *The Divine Governance in Reforming the Human Kingdom* (*Al-Tadbirat al-Ilahiyya fi Islah al-Mamlaka al-Insaniyya*), so we refrain from completing this chapter here for fear of prolixity. We also mentioned it in the exegesis of the Quran. Glory be to Him who is singular in nurturing His servants and who veiled those He veiled by means of mediations (الوسائط).

What emerges from this chapter for one who knows its spirit and meaning is that the Lord (الرب) is Allah, the Glorified, and that the worlds (العالمين) are the Universal Archetype (المثل الكلي). For this reason, He brought it into existence in the worlds upon eight letters, as a Throne (عرشا), and He established Himself upon it with gentleness, nurturing, tenderness, and the Compassionate Mercy (الرحمة الرحمانية) confirmed by the Specific Mercy (الرحيمية), to distinguish the animal abode. This is due to His saying: <<The Compassionate, the Merciful.>> He generalized with *Al-Rahman* and specialized with *Al-Rahim*. *Al-Rahman* operates in His world with mediations and without, while *Al-Rahim* operates in His Words without mediation, due to the existence of specialization and the honor of Divine Care (شرف العناية). Understand this, and the safest course is submission.

### A Section on His Saying, the Exalted: Master of the Day of Recompense

He means the Day of Recompense (يوم الجزاء). The Presence of Dominion (حضرة الملك) is from the station of Separation (مقام التفرقة), yet it is a Gathering (جمع), for Separation only occurs within Gathering. He said: <<In which every wise matter is determined.>> Thus, it is the station of Gathering, but having accepted the authority of Separation, it is also the station of Separation.
